Award.AwardTitle: Reactivities and Mechanisms for Group 14 Cation Radical Fragmentation Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Joseph Dinnocenzo of Rochester University, to provide fundamental mechanistic insight into the reactivities and reaction mechanisms of group 14 cation radical intermediates. The goal of this work is to elucidate the mechanism(s) for fragmentation reactions of aryltrialkyl-silane, -germane, -stannane, and -plumbane cation radicals. Professor Dinnocenzo will also develop methods for determining the stereochemical outcome of nucleophilic substitutions on group 14 cation radicals, and investigate the fragmentation mechanism(s) of oligosilane cation radicals.

Broader impacts of the research include training opportunities for students, using orbitals and bonds to drive research in organic synthesis resulting in new chemical transformations. Potential application of this work lies in the field of polysilane photoresists. Undergraduate participation in this research will be year-round through an established REU program at the University of Rochester. Dr. Dinnocenzo is actively recruiting from underepresented groups to his laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research from this NSF grant resulted in four major research outcomes. (1) Our kinetic studies on both ground and excited state electron transfers between a variety of electron donors and acceptors led to the surprising discovery that rate constant vs. reaction free energy plots followed a simple Sandros-Boltzmann type energy dependence. This was not expected based on numerous prior reports in the literature. Our findings, and our analysis of how to properly construct and interpret such electron transfer plots so that meaningful results can be obtained, will likely lead to the reinterpretation of a large body of previously published data that relied on flawed analyses and approaches. This will impact the fundamental understanding of electron transfers in chemistry, biology, and in materials science applications. (2) Investigations into the fragmentation of aryltrialkylstannane cation radicals revealed that these species display an unprecedented propensity to fragment to give the less stable aryl radical in preference to more stable alkyl radicals. Our research elucidated the mechanism of these unusual reactions. In addition to being mechanistically intriguing, these reactions have the potential to provide new methodology for the mild generation of aryl radicals that can be useful in both synthesis and materials science applications. (3) We developed several new transient absorption methods for accurately and precisely determining thermodynamically meaningful oxidation potentials of compounds that form highly reactive cation radical intermediates. The oxidation potentials measured by our new methods provide fundamentally important thermodynamic quantities and will be useful for critically testing a variety of thermodynamic and thermokinetic correlations. (4) While investigating photoinduced electron transfer reactions to N-alkoxypyridiniums, which lead to N–O bond cleavage and alkoxyl radical formation, we discovered an unprecedented reaction of alkoxyl radicals in which the alkoxyl radicals react with pyridines via proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) to produce 1H-pyridinyl radicals. The alkoxyl radicals act as hydrogen atom donors in these reactions, whereas the archetypal reaction of alkoxyl radicals is that they act as powerful hydrogen atom acceptors. The research provides new directions to pursue in alkoxyl radical chemistry, including the intriguing possibility that biologically relevant alkoxyl radicals may react with DNA and RNA bases in an analogous and previously unrecognized manner. 

Broader impacts of the project include support for the training of three graduate students, two of whom obtained their Ph.D. degrees during the grant period.  One of the Ph.D. students is currently employed as a research scientist in an industrial lab and the other is a university chemistry professor. Importantly, the grant also provided summer research support for two undergraduate students, both of whom are currently in chemistry graduate programs pursuing advanced degrees.


Last Modified: 11/17/2015
Modified by: Joseph P Dinnocenzo
